essays.title: The Purpose of Science
essays.question:
The most important aim of science should be to improve people's lives.
To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?
body_paragraphs: Science is often judged by the comfort and security it brings to ordinary people. I agree that improving human lives should be a major aim of scientific work, because public resources and public trust are involved. However, I do not think this aim should be interpreted so narrowly that we discourage basic research whose benefits are unpredictable.

In the most obvious sense, science improves lives when it targets urgent human needs. Medical research has reduced suffering through vaccines, antibiotics and safer surgery, while public health science has delivered clean water and better sanitation. Similarly, research into renewable energy, climate forecasting and drought-resistant crops can prevent crises rather than merely respond to them. When scientific priorities are linked to wellbeing in this way, societies gain measurable returns in the form of longer lives, higher productivity and greater resilience.

That said, the line from discovery to improved living standards is not always direct. Many breakthroughs that now underpin modern life emerged from curiosity-driven inquiry. Early research into electricity and magnetism, for example, was not intended to create smartphones or high-speed trains, yet it eventually made both possible. If every project had to show an immediate impact on quality of life, researchers would avoid long-term questions and we would lose the foundational knowledge that later generates life-changing applications.

In my view, the best position is to treat human wellbeing as the ultimate destination but allow multiple routes to reach it. Governments and universities should fund a balanced portfolio: mission-oriented work for pressing problems, alongside fundamental research that expands understanding. This combination both solves today's challenges and seeds tomorrow's innovations.
Overall, improving people's lives should be the central justification for science in society, but it should not become a restrictive rule that prevents exploration and long-term progress.

essays.title: University Students: Breadth vs Specialisation
essays.question:
Some university students want to learn about other subjects in addition to their main subjects. Others believe it is more important to give all their time and attention to studying for a qualification.
Discuss both these views and give your own opinion.
body_paragraphs: University students often face a choice between specialising deeply in one discipline and studying a wider range of subjects. Both approaches can be beneficial, but I believe students should prioritise their main qualification while taking a limited number of carefully selected electives.

Those who support studying additional subjects argue that most real-world problems are interdisciplinary. A software developer, for instance, may need psychology to design user-friendly products, and a business graduate may require statistics to evaluate evidence. Learning outside a major can therefore produce graduates who communicate across fields, think creatively and adapt to changing job markets. Moreover, exposure to arts, history or philosophy can develop judgement and ethical awareness, which are valuable in professions that increasingly affect society through technology and policy.

On the other hand, advocates of full concentration point out that a degree is primarily a signal of competence. Many programmes are already demanding, with intensive reading, laboratory work or professional placements. If students spread their time across unrelated subjects, they may fail to master the core content needed for employment or licensing. This is particularly relevant in medicine, engineering and accounting, where gaps in foundational knowledge can have serious consequences.

In my opinion, universities should encourage breadth, but not at the expense of depth. The most sensible model is to keep the major as the central focus while allowing students to choose a small number of electives that either strengthen transferable skills or complement their main field. With sensible limits and good academic advising, students can become both capable specialists and well-rounded thinkers.
Therefore, while broad learning has clear advantages, the main subject and qualification should remain the priority for most university students.

essays.title: Declining Countryside Populations
essays.question:
In many countries around the world, rural people are moving to cities, so the population in the countryside is decreasing.
Do you think this is a positive or a negative development?
body_paragraphs: In many parts of the world, people are leaving rural areas for cities, leading to shrinking populations in the countryside. Although urban migration can improve individual opportunities, I believe the overall trend is more negative than positive because it harms rural communities and intensifies urban problems.

It is true that moving to cities can raise living standards. Urban centres usually offer more diverse employment, better schools and easier access to hospitals and public services. For governments, concentrating people in one place can reduce the cost of infrastructure, because providing transport, electricity and specialist healthcare to remote villages is expensive. From this perspective, migration may look like an efficient path to development.

However, rural decline carries serious social and economic costs. When young adults move away, villages lose workers, entrepreneurs and future parents, which accelerates ageing and reduces local demand for shops and services. Schools close due to a lack of children, public transport becomes unviable, and loneliness increases among the elderly who remain. At the same time, cities may struggle to absorb newcomers. Housing shortages, high rents, traffic congestion and air pollution worsen, and public services such as water supply, waste management and clinics can become overstretched. In extreme cases, informal settlements expand, creating new inequalities and health risks.

A healthier outcome would be balanced development that reduces the pressure to migrate. Governments can invest in rural broadband, modern farming technology and small-town industries so that people can build careers outside major cities. Better transport links and remote work options can also make rural life compatible with professional ambition.
In conclusion, while city migration can benefit many individuals, the hollowing out of the countryside and the strain placed on urban areas make this, on balance, a negative development.

essays.title: Ageing Populations
essays.question:
In many countries, people are now living longer than ever before. Some people say an ageing population creates problems for governments. Other people think there are benefits if society has more elderly people.
To what extent do the advantages of having an ageing population outweigh the disadvantages?
body_paragraphs: Rising life expectancy has produced societies with a growing share of older people. This trend brings certain advantages, such as greater experience and stronger family support, but I believe the disadvantages outweigh the benefits in most countries unless major policy changes are made.

One benefit is that longer lives often reflect success in healthcare, nutrition and safety. Older citizens can also contribute to society in non-economic ways. Many provide childcare for grandchildren, volunteer in local organisations and offer wisdom in community decision-making. In workplaces that allow flexible retirement, experienced staff can mentor younger employees and reduce skills shortages.

Nevertheless, an ageing population creates heavy financial and structural pressures. Pension systems depend on a stable ratio of workers to retirees, and as that ratio falls, governments face painful choices: higher taxes, reduced benefits or increased public debt. Healthcare and social care spending also rises because chronic conditions are more common in later life and may require long-term support. Beyond budgets, labour shortages can slow economic growth, making it harder to fund public services. In some places, ageing electorates may also resist reforms, delaying necessary adjustments to housing, transport and education.

These problems can be managed, but doing so is difficult. Governments may need to raise retirement ages gradually, invest in preventive healthcare, support lifelong learning and make it easier for women and older adults to remain in the workforce. Selective immigration and automation can help, but both require careful planning to maintain social cohesion.

Overall, ageing societies can be rich in knowledge and social contribution, yet the fiscal strain and service demands are likely to outweigh these benefits. Without substantial reforms, the disadvantages remain dominant.

essays.title: Taking Risks in Life
essays.question:
It is important for people to take risks, both in their professional lives and their personal lives.
Do you think the advantages of taking risks outweigh the disadvantages?
body_paragraphs: Some people argue that risk-taking is essential in both careers and private life. In my view, the advantages generally outweigh the disadvantages, provided that risks are calculated rather than reckless.

The main advantage of taking risks is that it creates opportunities that would otherwise never appear. Professionally, changing jobs, starting a business or moving to a new city can lead to higher income and faster skill development. Personally, taking the initiative to form new friendships, learn a language or pursue a relationship can widen one's horizons and increase happiness. In many cases, the cost of inaction is invisible but significant: people may remain in unfulfilling routines simply because they fear uncertainty.

A second benefit is that risk-taking builds resilience. Even when outcomes are disappointing, individuals learn how to cope with setbacks, make better decisions and recover from failure. This emotional flexibility is increasingly valuable in a world where industries evolve quickly and job security is less predictable. Someone who has taken risks before is typically better prepared to adapt when change is unavoidable.

Of course, risks can lead to real harm. Poor financial decisions may produce debt, and impulsive personal choices can damage relationships or health. However, these dangers can be reduced through planning and moderation. For example, entrepreneurs can test a business idea on a small scale before leaving secure employment, and travellers can manage personal safety by researching destinations and taking sensible precautions.

In conclusion, taking risks brings the possibility of failure, but the potential gains in opportunity and personal growth are usually greater. The key is to approach risk as a strategic choice rather than a gamble.

essays.title: Professionals Working Where They Trained
essays.question:
Some people believe that professionals such as doctors and engineers should be required to work in the country where they did their training. Others believe they should be free to work in another country if they wish.
Discuss both these views and give your own opinion.
body_paragraphs: There is debate about whether highly trained professionals should be obliged to work in the country where they were educated or whether they should have complete freedom to move abroad. While the first view is understandable, I believe professionals should be free to choose where they work, and governments should use incentives rather than restrictions to retain talent.

Supporters of compulsory local service argue that training is often subsidised. Taxpayers fund universities, hospitals and scholarships, so it seems fair that graduates repay society by serving local communities, especially in areas with shortages. This is particularly persuasive for doctors, because rural regions may lack adequate healthcare. In addition, retaining skilled workers can prevent "brain drain" and protect national development, since engineers and medical specialists contribute directly to infrastructure and public health.

However, forcing people to stay can be both unfair and ineffective. Professionals invest years of effort, and sometimes large debts, to qualify; they may also have family reasons for relocating or seek better working conditions. If governments impose strict rules, some students may simply train overseas in the first place, worsening the very shortages the policy aims to solve. Moreover, mobility can benefit home countries through remittances, international networks and returning expertise. Many migrants eventually come back with advanced skills and new perspectives.

A more realistic solution is to make local work attractive. Higher salaries in underserved areas, improved hospital equipment, clearer career pathways and supportive working environments can encourage professionals to remain voluntarily. Another approach is a limited, well-designed service requirement tied to scholarships, where students knowingly accept an obligation in exchange for funding.

Overall, although societies deserve returns on public investment, personal freedom and practical outcomes matter. Incentives and better conditions are preferable to compulsory restrictions on where professionals may work.

essays.title: Children Spending Hours on Smartphones
essays.question:
Some children spend hours every day on their smartphones.
Why is this the case?
Do you think this is a positive or negative development?
body_paragraphs: It is increasingly common for children to spend several hours a day using smartphones. This happens for a combination of educational, social and technological reasons, and I believe the trend is largely negative because of its impact on health and development.

One reason is that smartphones are now integrated into daily life, including schoolwork. Many teachers assign research tasks, online quizzes or group projects that rely on messaging apps and digital platforms. Since phones are portable and always available, children naturally use them to complete homework as well as to check schedules and communicate with classmates. A second factor is social pressure. Friendships among young people often revolve around social media and group chats, and children may worry about missing updates or being excluded if they are not constantly connected.

In addition, smartphone applications are deliberately designed to keep users engaged. Short videos, game rewards and endless scrolling provide quick dopamine hits, making it hard for children to self-regulate. When parents are busy, giving a child a phone can also function as a convenient babysitter, further increasing screen time.

Despite some benefits, such as access to information and improved digital skills, I consider the overall effect negative. Excessive use can crowd out physical activity, sleep and face-to-face interaction, all of which are crucial for healthy growth. Constant online exposure may also increase anxiety, especially when children compare themselves to curated images or encounter cyberbullying. Moreover, attention spans can suffer when children become accustomed to rapid, fragmented content.
To address this, parents and schools should set realistic limits, encourage offline hobbies and teach digital literacy, including how apps manipulate attention.

In conclusion, children use smartphones heavily due to education demands, social expectations and addictive design features. While phones have some value, the current level of use is more harmful than beneficial.

essays.title: Alternative Medicine vs Visiting a Doctor
essays.question:
Nowadays, a growing number of people with health problems are trying alternative medicines and treatments instead of visiting their usual doctor.
Do you think this is a positive or negative development?
body_paragraphs: In recent years, more people have chosen alternative treatments rather than consulting medical doctors. Although some non-traditional approaches can complement standard care, I believe this trend is generally negative because it increases the risk of delayed diagnosis and ineffective treatment.

One explanation for the rise of alternative medicine is dissatisfaction with modern healthcare. In many countries, clinics are crowded, appointments are brief and patients feel unheard. Alternative practitioners often offer longer consultations and a sense of personal attention, which can be appealing. Another factor is the spread of health information online. Social media platforms frequently promote herbal cures, detox programmes and other unverified claims, and these messages can appear more persuasive than cautious medical advice.

However, replacing professional medical care with unproven remedies can be dangerous. Many serious illnesses, such as diabetes or cancer, require early diagnosis and evidence-based treatment. If patients rely on alternative therapies first, they may waste valuable time and allow conditions to worsen. In addition, the safety and quality of some products is uncertain because they are not regulated as strictly as prescription medicines. Interactions between herbal supplements and prescribed drugs can also cause harm.

That said, certain alternative practices may have limited benefits when used responsibly, especially for stress reduction and pain management. Techniques such as mindfulness, yoga or acupuncture can improve wellbeing and sometimes reduce the need for medication. The key is that these should be used alongside, not instead of, professional medical supervision.

In conclusion, the growing preference for alternative treatments is mostly a negative development. While complementary therapies can support overall health, abandoning doctors in favour of unverified remedies creates unnecessary risks for individuals and for public health.

essays.title: Researching the History of a House
essays.question:
In some countries, more people are becoming interested in finding out about the history of the house or building they live in.
What are the reasons for this?
How can people research this question?
body_paragraphs: In many places, residents are increasingly curious about the history of their homes. This interest is driven by practical concerns as well as cultural and personal motivations, and there are several reliable ways to investigate a building's past.

A major reason is safety and financial protection. Homeowners want to know whether a property has structural problems, past flooding, illegal renovations or unresolved disputes. Discovering such issues early can prevent expensive repairs and protect property value. Another motivation is identity and curiosity. People often feel more connected to a place when they understand who lived there before, how the neighbourhood developed and whether the building has historical significance. In older cities, a home might even be linked to notable events or architectural styles, which adds a sense of pride.

To research a property's history, the most direct method is to consult official records. Land registries, local councils and planning departments often hold documents about ownership, building permits and renovations. Historical maps and census data can also reveal how an area changed over time. In addition, libraries and local archives may contain newspapers, photographs and heritage listings that mention the building or street. Another useful approach is to speak with long-term residents. Neighbours, previous owners and community organisations can provide details that are not written down, such as stories about past uses of the building or major incidents in the area.
Finally, modern tools make research easier. Online databases, genealogy websites and even social media groups focused on local history can connect people with experts and sources.

In summary, people investigate their homes because they want to manage risks and develop a stronger connection to where they live. By combining official records with community knowledge, it is often possible to build a clear picture of a building's past.

essays.title: Advertising that Emphasises 'New'
essays.question:
In their advertising, businesses nowadays usually emphasise that their products are new in some way.
Why is this?
Do you think it is a positive or negative development?
body_paragraphs: It is common for companies to promote products as "new" or "improved" in their advertising. This happens mainly because businesses compete for attention in crowded markets, and novelty is a powerful way to persuade consumers. Overall, I think this trend is mixed but slightly negative because it encourages unnecessary consumption.

The first reason for highlighting novelty is differentiation. When many brands sell similar items, a company needs a clear message that makes its product stand out. By claiming a new feature, a fresh design or a faster performance, advertisers create a sense that the product is superior or more modern than alternatives. This strategy also taps into consumer psychology: people often associate "new" with better quality and fear missing out if they do not upgrade.

Another reason is that rapid innovation, especially in electronics, creates genuine improvements that companies want to communicate. Smartphone cameras, battery life and security systems can improve each year, and consumers may benefit from knowing what has changed.

Despite these points, the emphasis on constant novelty can have negative consequences. It can normalise frequent replacement even when older products still work well, leading to waste and environmental damage. It also pushes consumers towards impulsive buying and debt, particularly when marketing suggests that social status depends on owning the latest model. In addition, some "innovations" are cosmetic, designed mainly to restart the buying cycle rather than solve real problems.

A more positive direction would be to advertise durability, repairability and long-term value. Governments can also support this by requiring clearer information about product lifespan and by promoting right-to-repair policies.

In conclusion, businesses emphasise that products are new because novelty helps them compete and drive sales. While genuine innovation can be useful, the broader culture of constant upgrading makes this development slightly more negative than positive.

essays.title: Taxing Sugary Products
essays.question:
Many manufactured food and drink products contain high levels of sugar, which causes many health problems. Sugary products should be made more expensive to encourage people to consume less sugar.
Do you agree or disagree?
body_paragraphs: High sugar consumption is linked to obesity, diabetes and tooth decay, and processed foods and drinks are a major source. I largely agree that making sugary products more expensive can reduce intake, but price measures should be combined with education and healthier alternatives to be fair and effective.

Raising prices through a sugar tax can influence behaviour in the same way that higher tobacco prices reduce smoking. Many consumers, especially teenagers, buy sweet drinks impulsively, so even a small increase can discourage frequent purchases. In addition, manufacturers may reformulate products to avoid the tax, lowering sugar levels across the market without requiring individual willpower. Several countries have reported such reformulation after introducing levies on soft drinks, which suggests the policy can shift industry practices as well as consumer choices.

However, price rises can also be regressive, affecting low-income families more than wealthy ones. For some households, cheap sweet snacks are an affordable treat, and higher prices may feel like punishment. This is why revenue from a sugar tax should be used transparently to benefit the public, for example by subsidising fruit and vegetables, funding school meal programmes, or improving community sports facilities. If healthier options are accessible and affordable, the policy is far more defensible.

Furthermore, taxation alone will not solve the problem. People may substitute other unhealthy foods if they do not understand nutrition labels or the long-term risks. Clear front-of-pack labelling and restrictions on advertising sugary products to children can reinforce the effect of price changes.

In conclusion, making sugary products more expensive is a sensible and evidence-based tool to reduce excessive sugar consumption. Yet it should be implemented alongside supportive measures so that it improves public health without unfairly burdening the poorest consumers.

essays.title: Driverless Vehicles
essays.question:
In the future all cars, buses, and trucks will be driverless. The only people travelling inside these vehicles would be passengers.
Do you think the advantages of driverless vehicles outweigh the disadvantages?
body_paragraphs: Autonomous vehicles are developing rapidly, and it is plausible that most transport will eventually be driverless. I believe the advantages outweigh the disadvantages, mainly because of improved safety and efficiency, although new risks will need careful management.

The strongest benefit is road safety. Human error causes the vast majority of traffic accidents, whether through distraction, fatigue or intoxication. Driverless systems can maintain constant attention, react faster than humans and follow traffic rules consistently. If autonomous fleets reduce collisions, they would also lessen the burden on hospitals and cut the social costs of disability and lost productivity.

A second advantage is efficiency. Self-driving vehicles could travel closer together, choose optimal routes and reduce congestion through coordinated movement. Freight transport might become cheaper and more reliable, lowering prices for consumers. In addition, driverless public transport could increase mobility for people who cannot drive, including the elderly and those with disabilities, improving social inclusion and access to work.

Nevertheless, there are disadvantages. Cybersecurity is a real concern: if systems are hacked, the consequences could be severe. There may also be job losses for drivers, which would require retraining and social support. Finally, during the transition period, mixed roads with human drivers and autonomous cars could create confusion and new types of accidents.

Despite these issues, most drawbacks can be mitigated. Strong regulation, rigorous testing, encrypted systems and clear liability rules can reduce safety and hacking risks. Governments can also plan for labour disruption by investing in training programmes and supporting workers into related roles such as vehicle maintenance, logistics coordination and software monitoring.

In summary, although driverless vehicles introduce technological and social challenges, their potential to save lives and improve transport efficiency means the advantages are likely to outweigh the disadvantages in the long run.

essays.title: Owning a Home vs Renting
essays.question:
In some countries owning a home rather than renting one is very important for people.
Why might this be the case?
Do you think this is a positive or negative situation?
body_paragraphs: In many societies, home ownership is seen as a major life goal, sometimes even more important than renting. This preference is usually driven by financial considerations and a desire for stability. Overall, I think it is positive in moderation, but it becomes negative when it creates unhealthy pressure and inequality.

One reason people value ownership is security. Renting can involve frequent moves, rent increases and uncertain contracts, which can be stressful for families with children. Owning a home provides a stable base for long-term relationships, schooling and community ties. Another reason is financial. Property is often considered a reliable investment because house prices tend to rise over time in many countries. Homeowners may also build equity instead of paying rent, which can help them fund retirement or support their children later.

However, an excessive obsession with ownership can have drawbacks. When society treats renting as a failure, people may buy homes they cannot afford, taking on risky mortgages and becoming vulnerable to interest-rate changes. In hot property markets, ownership can widen inequality, because those who already own assets benefit from rising prices while younger and poorer people are priced out. This can also distort economies, as too much money flows into real estate rather than productive business investment.

In my view, home ownership is beneficial when it is one option among many, not a social requirement. Governments can improve the balance by protecting renters' rights, increasing affordable housing supply and discouraging speculation. In this way, people can choose the housing model that fits their income and lifestyle.

To conclude, the desire to own a home is understandable and can bring stability and financial security. Yet when it becomes a cultural obsession, it can create debt and inequality, turning a positive goal into a harmful social trend.

essays.title: The Future of Printed Books and Newspapers
essays.question:
In the future, nobody will buy printed newspapers or books because they will be able to read everything they want online without paying.
To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?
body_paragraphs: Some people predict that printed newspapers and books will disappear because online content is widely available, often free of charge. I disagree with this view, because print offers unique practical and emotional value, and because quality journalism and publishing require sustainable business models.

First, many readers still prefer print for comfort and focus. A physical book does not require a battery, does not generate notifications and is easier on the eyes during long reading sessions. For students and professionals, paper can also aid concentration and memory, since it encourages deep reading rather than skimming. In addition, printed books have cultural and aesthetic value. People buy them as gifts, collect favourite authors, and display them at home, which digital files cannot replicate in the same way.

Second, the assumption that everything online will be free is unrealistic. Producing reliable news and well-edited books costs money. Even if some content is free, much is already behind paywalls or supported by subscriptions, donations or advertising. As misinformation grows, many readers are willing to pay for trusted sources. Similarly, publishers continue to invest in printing because there is a market for high-quality physical editions, especially for children's books, art books and textbooks.

This is not to deny that digital reading will expand. Online platforms are convenient, and e-books are useful for travel and for people who need adjustable fonts. However, convenience does not automatically eliminate other formats. Just as radio survived the arrival of television, print is likely to remain as a complementary medium.

In conclusion, although digital content will continue to grow, printed books and newspapers will not disappear entirely. Their advantages in reading experience, cultural meaning and the economics of quality production mean that many people will still choose to buy them.

essays.title: Is Advertising Still Effective?
essays.question:
Some people say that advertising is extremely successful at persuading us to buy things. Other people think that advertising is so common that we no longer pay attention to it.
Discuss both these views and give your own opinion.
body_paragraphs: Advertising is everywhere, from billboards to social media feeds, and opinions differ on whether it still influences consumer behaviour. While it is true that people often ignore many adverts, I believe advertising remains highly persuasive, especially when it is targeted and emotionally engaging.

Those who claim advertising is effective point to its ability to shape preferences and create brand recognition. Companies invest huge sums in marketing precisely because it tends to increase sales. Modern advertising also uses data to reach specific audiences. For example, someone searching online for running shoes may later see repeated adverts for sports brands, making a purchase more likely through constant reminders and perceived familiarity. Advertising can also associate products with desirable lifestyles, such as fitness, success or popularity, which can be particularly influential for young consumers.

On the other hand, critics argue that people have become numb to advertising due to overexposure. Many skip commercials, install ad blockers or scroll past sponsored posts without reading them. In busy urban environments, billboards and posters fade into the background. Furthermore, as consumers become more informed, they may distrust traditional advertising and instead rely on reviews, influencers or recommendations from friends.

In my view, both sides are correct in different ways. Generic adverts often fail because audiences are saturated, but well-designed campaigns still work. The difference is that persuasion now depends more on relevance and authenticity. Brands that understand customer needs, communicate clear value and build trust can still influence buying decisions, whereas noisy and repetitive advertising is increasingly ignored.

In conclusion, advertising has not lost its power; it has simply evolved. Although people overlook much of the marketing around them, targeted and credible advertising continues to persuade consumers to buy.

essays.title: Telling Children They Can Achieve Anything
essays.question:
In some cultures, children are often told that they can achieve anything if they try hard enough.
What are the advantages and disadvantages of giving children this message?
body_paragraphs: Many parents and teachers encourage children by telling them that hard work can achieve any goal. This message has clear advantages, particularly for motivation and confidence, but it can also create unrealistic expectations and unnecessary stress.

On the positive side, believing that effort matters can foster persistence. Children who think success is possible are more likely to practise, seek feedback and recover after failure. This mindset is useful in education, where improvement often comes from repeated effort rather than instant talent. It can also empower children from disadvantaged backgrounds, who may otherwise assume that their circumstances determine their future. For example, a student from a low-income family may be inspired to study diligently if they believe achievement is within their control.

However, the message becomes harmful when it ignores real constraints. Not everyone can become an Olympic athlete or a world-famous musician, no matter how hard they try, because genetic ability, timing and opportunity also play roles. If children interpret the slogan literally, they may blame themselves for outcomes beyond their control, leading to anxiety and low self-esteem. Another drawback is that some children may pursue unsuitable goals for too long, wasting time that could be spent developing strengths in other areas.

A healthier approach is to combine encouragement with realism. Adults can praise effort while teaching children to set flexible goals and evaluate progress. They can also emphasise that success has many forms, including personal growth and contribution to others, not only elite achievement.

In conclusion, telling children they can achieve anything can build ambition and resilience, but it may also create pressure and disappointment. The best message is that hard work greatly increases chances of success, while wise goal-setting and self-awareness remain essential.

essays.title: Accepting a Bad Situation vs Improving It
essays.question:
Some people believe that it is best to accept a bad situation, such as an unsatisfactory job or shortage of money. Others argue that it is better to try and improve such situations.
Discuss both these views and give your own opinion.
body_paragraphs: When people face an unpleasant job or financial hardship, some prefer acceptance while others insist on changing the situation. Both attitudes have value, but I believe it is generally better to try to improve one's circumstances, while accepting what cannot realistically be changed.

Those who recommend acceptance argue that many factors are outside personal control. Economic downturns, illness or family responsibilities can limit options, and constant resistance may create stress and bitterness. By accepting reality, people can protect their mental health and focus on what they can manage day to day. For instance, someone in a temporary low-paid job might accept it for a period while maintaining a positive outlook, rather than feeling defeated.

However, acceptance can easily become passive resignation. Trying to improve a bad situation often leads to better outcomes and a stronger sense of agency. People can upgrade skills, seek new employment, negotiate working conditions or create a budget to reduce financial pressure. Even small steps, such as taking evening classes or applying for internships, can gradually change a person's trajectory. Moreover, problem-solving tends to build confidence, making individuals more capable of handling future difficulties.

In my opinion, the key difference is between accepting emotions and accepting outcomes. It is sensible to accept that a situation is currently difficult, but it is unwise to assume it must remain that way. People should calmly evaluate what is changeable and take practical action, while also recognising limits and avoiding unrealistic expectations.

In conclusion, acceptance may reduce stress in the short term, but improving a bad situation usually offers greater long-term benefits. A balanced approach is to accept reality as a starting point and then work strategically to make life better.

essays.title: The Most Serious Environmental Problem
essays.question:
Some people say that the main environmental problem of our time is the loss of particular species of plants and animals. Others say that there are more important environmental problems.
Discuss both these views and give your own opinion.
body_paragraphs: Environmental debates often focus on whether species extinction is the most urgent issue or whether broader problems deserve more attention. While biodiversity loss is extremely serious, I believe larger systemic threats such as climate change and pollution are even more critical, partly because they drive extinction in the first place.

Those who prioritise species loss argue that every organism plays a role in ecosystems, and removing one species can trigger cascading damage. For example, the decline of pollinators threatens food production, while the loss of predators can lead to overpopulation of certain animals and destruction of habitats. Biodiversity also has economic and medical value: many medicines originate from plants, and diverse ecosystems provide services such as water purification and soil protection.

However, others contend that climate change, air pollution and plastic waste are more urgent. Rising temperatures intensify droughts, floods and wildfires, threatening human settlements and agriculture on a massive scale. Pollution, meanwhile, directly harms human health through respiratory disease and contaminated water. These problems affect billions of people and can destabilise economies and migration patterns. Importantly, they also accelerate biodiversity loss by destroying habitats and altering conditions faster than species can adapt.

In my view, treating extinction as the single main problem can be misleading. It is better to tackle root causes. Reducing carbon emissions, regulating industrial pollution and changing unsustainable consumption patterns would protect human wellbeing and slow the destruction of habitats, which would in turn reduce species loss. Conservation programmes are still essential, but they will fail if the planet's climate and oceans continue to deteriorate.

In conclusion, species extinction is a tragedy and a warning sign, yet broader environmental crises are more fundamental. Addressing climate change and pollution should be the highest priority because doing so also safeguards biodiversity.

essays.title: Music Bringing People Together
essays.question:
Some people say that music is a good way of bringing people of different cultures and ages together.
To what extent do you agree or disagree with this opinion?
body_paragraphs: Music is often described as a universal language, and many believe it can unite people across cultures and generations. I strongly agree with this view because music creates shared emotional experiences and provides a safe bridge for cultural exchange.

Firstly, music connects people through feelings that do not require translation. Even when listeners do not understand lyrics, rhythm and melody can communicate joy, sadness or hope. At concerts, festivals or even weddings, strangers often sing and dance together, forming a temporary community. This shared experience can reduce social distance and encourage openness, particularly in multicultural societies where people may otherwise remain within their own groups.

Secondly, music introduces audiences to other cultures in an accessible way. Traditional instruments, musical scales and performance styles reflect history and identity, and learning about them can increase respect rather than suspicion. For instance, international music festivals allow people to experience unfamiliar genres, such as Afrobeat or classical Indian music, while interacting with performers and fans from different backgrounds. This can spark curiosity about food, language and customs, supporting wider cultural understanding.

Music also crosses age boundaries. Older generations may introduce young people to classic songs, while younger listeners share new trends through streaming platforms. Although tastes differ, many families bond by singing together in the car or attending live events. Even when preferences are not identical, discussing music can become a positive conversation starter between grandparents and teenagers.

Of course, music does not erase deep social conflicts, and some songs may reinforce stereotypes. However, as a tool for connection, it is uniquely powerful because it is enjoyable and widely available.

In conclusion, I agree to a great extent that music can bring different cultures and age groups together. By creating shared emotions and encouraging cultural curiosity, it helps people build connections that might not otherwise exist.

essays.title: Choosing Self-Employment
essays.question:
Nowadays many people choose to be self-employed, rather than to work for a company or organisation.
Why might this be the case?
What could be the disadvantages of being self-employed?
body_paragraphs: In recent years, self-employment has become more common in many countries. This shift is largely driven by changing technology and attitudes towards work, but it also comes with notable disadvantages, particularly in income stability and personal wellbeing.

One reason people choose self-employment is autonomy. Working for oneself allows greater control over working hours, clients and projects, which can improve work-life balance for parents or those with caregiving responsibilities. Another factor is opportunity created by the digital economy. Online platforms make it easy to sell services such as graphic design, tutoring or software development to a global market. In addition, some people are attracted by the possibility of higher earnings and the satisfaction of building something of their own, especially if traditional jobs offer limited promotion or low wages.

Despite these benefits, self-employment can be risky. Income may be irregular, particularly at the beginning, and freelancers often lack paid holidays, sick leave and employer-provided pensions. This insecurity can be stressful and may discourage long-term planning such as buying a home or starting a family. Self-employed workers must also handle administrative tasks, including taxes, marketing and customer service, which can reduce the time available for their main work. Furthermore, isolation is common because there are fewer colleagues and less social support.

To reduce these disadvantages, governments can modernise labour protections by offering affordable health insurance and retirement schemes for independent workers. Individuals can also manage risk by building savings, diversifying clients and developing strong professional networks.

In conclusion, many people become self-employed for flexibility, online opportunities and potential financial rewards. However, the lack of stability, benefits and social support means self-employment is not suitable for everyone, and it requires careful preparation to be sustainable.

essays.question:
In many cities the use of private cars is increasing and causing problems.
Why is this happening?
What measures could be taken to encourage people to use public transport?
body_paragraphs: In many cities, public transport is criticised for being unreliable and overcrowded, and this leads some people to rely heavily on private cars. Although driving can be convenient in the short term, I believe improving mass transit is the most effective way to reduce congestion and pollution over the long run.

People often prefer cars because they offer door-to-door travel and a sense of control. For commuters with irregular working hours, buses and trains may not run frequently enough, forcing long waits and missed connections. Moreover, a car provides privacy and personal space, which matters after a tiring day at work. Cars also make it easier to carry children, groceries or work equipment, which is particularly important in suburbs where services are spread out and walking is impractical.

However, widespread car use has serious drawbacks. Traffic jams waste time and fuel, lowering productivity and increasing commuting stress. Exhaust emissions and brake dust worsen air quality, raising rates of asthma and other respiratory illness. In addition, expanding roads and parking spaces consumes urban land that could otherwise be used for parks, housing or cycle lanes. The result is a less liveable city that prioritises vehicles over people.

To address the problem, governments should invest in fast, integrated and affordable public transport. Dedicated bus lanes, extended metro lines and well-designed interchanges can make journeys predictable and reduce total travel time. Reliability can also be improved with real-time timetable apps and clear disruption alerts. Pricing policies matter too: subsidised monthly passes encourage regular use, while congestion charges or limited parking can discourage unnecessary driving in city centres.

In conclusion, many people choose cars because they are flexible and comfortable, yet the social and environmental costs are high. By modernising public transport and managing road demand, cities can make sustainable travel the default option rather than a sacrifice.

essays.title: Will Online Education Replace Classrooms?
essays.question:
Some people think that online education will replace classroom teaching in the future.
Do you agree or disagree?
body_paragraphs: Some people argue that online education will eventually replace traditional classrooms. While digital learning has clear advantages, I disagree that it can fully substitute face-to-face teaching, because schools provide structure, social development and practical training that are hard to replicate online.

Online courses are appealing for their flexibility and scale. Learners can watch lectures at any time, pause and replay difficult sections, and choose modules from international universities without relocating. This is beneficial for working adults and people in remote areas. In addition, digital platforms can personalise practice exercises using instant feedback and adaptive quizzes, helping students progress at their own pace and identify weaknesses quickly.

Nevertheless, physical classrooms offer irreplaceable benefits. Many studentsâ€”particularly childrenâ€”need external discipline to stay focused, and a teacherâ€™s presence reduces procrastination and keeps learners accountable. Education is also about communication, teamwork and confidence, which develop through live discussion, presentations and everyday interaction with peers. Furthermore, subjects such as laboratory science, engineering and the performing arts require hands-on equipment and immediate guidance to ensure safety and mastery. Schools also provide pastoral support, including counselling and special-needs assistance, that is harder to deliver effectively in a purely virtual setting.

A more realistic future is blended learning. Schools can use online tools for homework, revision and assessment, while reserving classroom time for interaction, experiments and mentoring. For example, a â€œflipped classroomâ€ lets students learn theory via videos at home and then solve problems collaboratively in class, making teaching time more efficient without removing the human element.

In conclusion, online education will continue to expand because it is convenient and accessible, but it is unlikely to replace classrooms entirely. A hybrid approach can combine the reach of technology with the motivation and community that in-person schooling provides.

essays.title: Responsibility for Reducing Pollution
essays.question:
Some people believe that individuals are mainly responsible for reducing pollution.
Others say that governments and large companies should take the main responsibility.
Discuss both views and give your own opinion.
body_paragraphs: Pollution and climate change have become defining challenges of our time. Some argue that ordinary citizens should take primary responsibility for reducing environmental damage, whereas others believe governments and corporations hold the key. In my view, both levels must act, but systemic policies from powerful institutions are essential to make individual effort effective.

Individuals can certainly make a difference through daily choices. Using public transport, reducing meat consumption and avoiding single-use plastics lower personal carbon footprints. Consumers also influence markets: when enough people buy energy-efficient appliances or choose refillable products, firms respond by expanding greener options. Moreover, community actions such as neighbourhood clean-ups and recycling programmes raise awareness and create social norms that discourage wasteful behaviour.

However, expecting citizens to solve pollution alone is unrealistic. Major emissions come from electricity generation, heavy industry and large-scale logistics, which are controlled by companies and regulated by states. Without strict standards, a person can recycle diligently yet still live in a city powered by coal or surrounded by diesel trucks. Governments can introduce carbon pricing, enforce emission limits, ban the most harmful pollutants and invest in renewable infrastructure. Meanwhile, businesses can redesign supply chains, switch to sustainable materials and publish transparent environmental reports so that progress can be measured and verified.

The best results come when policy and personal behaviour reinforce each other. For instance, if authorities build reliable metro systems and safe cycle lanes, people are more likely to leave their cars at home. Similarly, if companies offer affordable eco-friendly products, consumers can choose them without feeling that sustainability is a luxury.

In conclusion, individuals should adopt responsible habits, but meaningful progress depends on government regulation and corporate innovation. Environmental protection works best as a shared project in which institutions change the system and citizens respond with cleaner lifestyles.

essays.title: The Influence of Advertising
essays.question:
Advertising encourages people to buy things they do not really need.
To what extent do you agree or disagree?
What measures can be taken to reduce the negative effects of advertising?
body_paragraphs: Advertising is a powerful feature of modern economies, appearing on streets, television and social media feeds. I largely agree that it can push consumers towards unnecessary purchases, although it also provides useful information. The key issue is to limit manipulative marketing while keeping transparent communication between businesses and customers.

Many adverts are designed to create artificial needs. By linking products with status, beauty or happiness, companies persuade people that buying a new phone or fashionable clothing will improve their identity. This is especially visible online, where influencers promote items in carefully edited videos and encourage impulse buying with limited-time discounts. As a result, households may overspend, accumulate debt and feel constant dissatisfaction with what they already own.

On the other hand, advertising is not inherently harmful. It helps new firms enter the market, informs consumers about prices and features, and can raise awareness of beneficial services such as health check-ups or educational courses. In competitive industries, adverts may even lead to lower prices because companies must attract customers more efficiently. When advertising is factual and verifiable, it supports informed choice rather than emotional pressure.

To reduce the negative impact, governments can regulate how products are promoted. Clear rules should require paid endorsements to be labelled, restrict targeting of children and ban misleading claims about â€œmiracleâ€ outcomes. Schools should teach media literacy so that students learn to recognise emotional manipulation and evaluate evidence. Individuals can also limit exposure by using ad blockers and adopting a 24-hour waiting rule for non-essential purchases.

In conclusion, advertising often encourages people to buy beyond their real needs, particularly in the digital age. With stronger regulation and better consumer education, marketing can be made more honest, less wasteful and more compatible with long-term wellbeing.

essays.title: Studying or Working Abroad
essays.question:
Many young people choose to study or work in a different country.
What are the advantages and disadvantages of this trend?
body_paragraphs: An increasing number of young adults choose to study or work in another country for several years. This trend offers significant benefits, particularly in career development and personal growth, but it can also create challenges such as cultural stress and weakened family ties.

One major advantage is improved employment prospects. International experience can strengthen a CV, especially in fields like finance, technology and hospitality where companies serve global clients. Living abroad also develops transferable skills, including independence, problem-solving and cross-cultural communication, because daily tasks must be handled without familiar support. In addition, students who attend overseas universities may access better research facilities or specialised programmes that are unavailable at home, which can accelerate their professional development. Finally, friendships with people from different backgrounds often broaden attitudes and reduce prejudice.

However, the disadvantages should not be ignored. Adjusting to a different language and social norms can be exhausting, and many newcomers experience loneliness in the first months. The cost of living and tuition fees may also be higher, leading to debt or the need to work long hours alongside study. Furthermore, prolonged absence can strain relationships with parents and friends, and some migrants feel they no longer fully belong in either culture when they return.

To maximise the benefits, young people should plan carefully by budgeting realistically, learning basic language skills before departure and building support networks through clubs or mentorship programmes. Governments and universities can also help by providing orientation services and affordable counselling for international students and workers.

In conclusion, going abroad can open doors and broaden perspectives, yet it involves financial and emotional risks. With preparation and appropriate support, the advantages are likely to outweigh the disadvantages for many young people.

essays.title: Remote Work as the New Normal
essays.question:
More employees are now able to work from home.
What are the advantages and disadvantages of this development?
body_paragraphs: Remote work has expanded rapidly as companies adopt digital tools and flexible policies. It brings clear benefits for workers and employers, yet it also creates challenges for productivity, collaboration and wellbeing.

A major advantage is flexibility. People can arrange their day around family duties and avoid long commutes, saving time and transport costs. Many businesses also benefit by hiring talent from other cities and reducing office rent. In addition, working from home can improve concentration for tasks that require deep focus, because employees face fewer interruptions than in open-plan offices.

However, remote work is not ideal for everyone. Some workers struggle to separate work from personal life, which can lead to longer hours and burnout. Communication may become less efficient when teams rely on messages instead of quick face-to-face discussion, and new employees can find it harder to learn informally from colleagues. Finally, not all homes provide a quiet workspace, so inequality can increase between those with good living conditions and those without.

In conclusion, working from home offers flexibility and cost savings, but it can weaken teamwork and blur boundaries. A balanced approach, such as hybrid schedules and clear expectations about availability, is likely to deliver the best outcomes.

essays.title: Should Governments Fund the Arts?
essays.question:
Governments should spend more money on healthcare and education than on art such as music and theatre.
To what extent do you agree or disagree?
body_paragraphs: Public budgets are limited, so governments must prioritise. While healthcare and education are essential services, I disagree that funding the arts should be treated as a luxury, because cultural investment also supports social wellbeing and economic activity.

It is true that hospitals and schools deserve major funding. High-quality healthcare saves lives, and education builds the skills needed for national productivity. In poorer regions, money spent on vaccination programmes or teacher training may deliver immediate, measurable benefits that outweigh almost any other investment.

Nevertheless, the arts play a vital role in society. Museums, concerts and community theatres strengthen identity, provide affordable leisure and improve mental health by reducing stress and loneliness. Cultural industries also create jobs, attract tourism and support local businesses. Importantly, arts funding does not have to compete directly with essential services; modest grants can sustain libraries, festivals and youth programmes at relatively low cost compared with large infrastructure projects in health and education.

Overall, healthcare and education should remain top priorities, but governments should still allocate stable funding to the arts. A healthy society is not only well treated and well trained, but also inspired and socially connected.

essays.title: Starting School Earlier
essays.question:
Some people think children should start school as early as possible, while others believe they should begin at least at age seven.
Discuss both views and give your own opinion.
body_paragraphs: There is ongoing debate about the best age for children to start formal education. Supporters of early schooling argue it builds skills sooner, whereas others believe young children need more time to play and develop at home. I believe a later start is generally better, with optional pre-school for families who want it.

Those in favour of early schooling point to academic advantages. Early literacy and numeracy classes may help children adapt to structured learning and reduce gaps between students from different backgrounds. Schools can also provide routines, social interaction and access to trained teachers, which may be valuable in households where parents are busy or lack educational resources.

On the other hand, starting too early can create stress. At ages five or six, many children learn best through play, movement and imagination, and long periods of sitting still may harm motivation. Delaying school can allow emotional maturity to develop, making it easier for children to follow instructions and cooperate with peers. Countries with later school entry often emphasise play-based kindergarten, which can prepare children without academic pressure.

In conclusion, early schooling can support skill-building, but it may also undermine natural development. A flexible system that offers play-based early years and formal schooling around seven is, in my view, the most child-friendly approach.

essays.question:

Why is this happening?
What can be done to encourage people to eat a healthier diet?

In addition, delivery apps have reduced the effort required to order high-calorie meals, turning unhealthy choices into a default habit.

At the personal level, people can plan simple meals, learn basic cooking skills and keep healthy snacks available to reduce impulsive purchases.

In summary, fast food is popular because it is quick, cheap and aggressively promoted. By improving food environments and teaching practical nutrition habits, societies can help people shift towards healthier long-term choices.

essays.title: Social Media and Real Relationships
essays.question:
Some people believe that social media has made communication among people less personal.
To what extent do you agree or disagree?
body_paragraphs: Social media has transformed how people interact, allowing instant contact across long distances. I largely agree that it can make communication less personal, although it also helps maintain relationships that might otherwise disappear.

On the negative side, online messages often replace deeper conversation. Short texts and emojis are efficient, but they can reduce empathy because tone and body language are missing. Many users also curate idealised images of their lives, which encourages shallow comparison rather than honest sharing. As a result, people may feel connected on the surface while experiencing loneliness in reality.

However, social platforms can support meaningful bonds when used wisely. Families separated by work or migration can share daily updates, video-call regularly and celebrate milestones together. Social media also helps people find communities around niche interests or health conditions, providing emotional support that may be hard to access locally. In this sense, technology can extend, rather than replace, genuine relationships.

Overall, social media tends to make communication more superficial if it becomes a substitute for face-to-face interaction. The solution is not to abandon it, but to use it as a tool for arranging real meetings and sustaining long-term ties.

essays.title: Tourism and Local Culture
essays.question:
International tourism has increased greatly in recent years.
Do the advantages of this trend outweigh the disadvantages?
body_paragraphs: International tourism has grown rapidly due to cheaper travel and online booking. It brings economic benefits to many destinations, but it can also damage local culture and the environment. In my view, the advantages outweigh the disadvantages if tourism is managed responsibly.

Tourism creates jobs in hotels, transport, restaurants and entertainment, often in regions with few alternatives. It can also finance conservation and heritage restoration through entrance fees and taxes. Moreover, cultural exchange can be positive: visitors learn about different traditions, and local businesses gain incentives to preserve crafts, festivals and historical sites.

Yet there are real costs. Overcrowding raises housing prices, increases waste and puts pressure on water and transport systems. In some places, traditions are simplified into performances for tourists, which can weaken authenticity. Environmental harm is another concern, particularly in fragile coastal or mountain areas where infrastructure expands too quickly.

In conclusion, tourism is a powerful engine for development, but it needs clear rules, such as visitor caps, green transport and fair taxation. With sustainable planning, communities can enjoy the economic gains while protecting their culture and natural resources.

essays.title: Does Technology Complicate Life?

body_paragraphs: Modern technology shapes almost every part of daily life. Some argue it adds complexity, while others claim it simplifies routine tasks. I believe it has made life easier overall, though it requires new skills and self-control.

Technology clearly reduces effort in many areas. Online banking, navigation apps and digital government services save time that was previously spent in queues or searching for information. In the workplace, software automates repetitive tasks and enables remote collaboration, which can increase productivity and offer more flexibility. Medical technology also improves diagnosis and treatment, extending life expectancy in many countries.

At the same time, technology can create new complications. People must constantly update devices, manage passwords and protect themselves from scams and data leaks. Social media can be distracting and may increase anxiety through constant notifications. Furthermore, older adults or low-income groups may struggle with digital systems, which can exclude them from essential services.

Overall, technology has largely made life easier, but society must address digital inequality and promote healthy habits. With better education and responsible design, the benefits can be enjoyed without unnecessary stress.

essays.title: Punishment or Rehabilitation?
essays.question:
Some people think the best way to reduce crime is to give longer prison sentences.
Others believe there are better alternatives.
Discuss both views and give your own opinion.
body_paragraphs: Reducing crime is a major priority for governments. Some people support harsher sentences, believing fear of punishment deters offenders, while others argue that rehabilitation and prevention work better. I believe longer sentences are sometimes necessary, but alternatives are generally more effective at cutting reoffending.

Supporters of long prison terms claim they protect the public by keeping dangerous criminals away from society. Strong penalties may also discourage potential offenders, especially for violent crime. In addition, victims may feel that justice has been served when the punishment seems proportionate to the harm caused.

However, long imprisonment often fails to address the causes of crime, such as addiction, poor education and unemployment. Without treatment and training, many prisoners leave with the same problems and fewer job opportunities, which can push them back into illegal activity. Alternatives like counselling, vocational courses, community service and close supervision can help offenders build stable lives. Investing in youth programmes and mental-health services may also prevent crime before it happens.

In conclusion, prison is essential for serious offences, but simply increasing sentence length is not a complete solution. A balanced strategy that combines punishment with rehabilitation and prevention is the best way to reduce crime sustainably.

essays.title: Subsidising Renewable Energy
essays.question:
Some people think governments should subsidise renewable energy, while others believe energy markets should be left to private companies.
Discuss both views and give your own opinion.
body_paragraphs: As countries seek to reduce emissions, the question of who should drive the energy transition has become urgent. Some argue that subsidies for renewables are necessary, while others prefer free markets led by private firms. In my view, government support is essential in the early stages, alongside strong competition.

Those who oppose subsidies claim that markets allocate resources more efficiently. If renewable power is truly cost-effective, private companies will invest without taxpayer money. Critics also warn that subsidies can be wasted through corruption or poor planning, and that governments may choose fashionable technologies rather than the most practical options.

Nevertheless, renewable projects often face high upfront costs and infrastructure barriers. Public funding can accelerate innovation, build smart grids and reduce risk for investors, especially when fossil fuels still benefit from historical advantages and hidden environmental costs. Subsidies can also protect consumers during the transition by stabilising prices. Importantly, support can be designed to encourage efficiency, for example through competitive auctions and incentives that decline over time as the technology matures.

In conclusion, leaving everything to the market may slow progress on climate goals. Targeted government subsidies, combined with transparent regulation and private-sector competition, offer the most realistic path to clean and affordable energy.

essays.title: Animal Testing in Medical Research
essays.question:
Some people believe that using animals for medical research is necessary.
Others think it is cruel and should be stopped.
Discuss both views and give your own opinion.
body_paragraphs: Animal testing remains one of the most controversial issues in modern science. Supporters argue it is necessary for developing safe medicines, while opponents see it as unethical cruelty. I believe animal experiments should be reduced as much as possible, but not completely banned until reliable alternatives are widely available.

Proponents emphasise human safety. Before new drugs are given to volunteers, researchers need evidence about toxicity and side effects, and animal models can provide early warnings. Many medical breakthroughs, including vaccines and surgical techniques, were developed using animal trials. From this perspective, limited testing is justified if it prevents greater harm to humans.

However, the ethical concerns are serious. Animals can experience pain, stress and confinement, and some experiments are repeated for commercial rather than medical necessity. In addition, results from animals do not always predict human responses, which means suffering may occur without clear benefits. New methods such as organ-on-a-chip technology, computer modelling and cultured human cells are improving and can replace many tests, especially in cosmetics and minor products.

In conclusion, animal testing should be tightly regulated, restricted to essential research and paired with strong investment in alternatives. The long-term goal should be a future where medical progress no longer depends on animal suffering.

essays.title: Housing Pressure in Big Cities
essays.question:
In many countries, cities are becoming overcrowded and housing is becoming unaffordable.
What problems does this cause?
What measures can be taken to solve these problems?
body_paragraphs: Rapid urban growth has made housing in many cities increasingly expensive. This trend creates social and economic problems, but governments can reduce pressure through better planning, transport and housing policy.

Unaffordable housing widens inequality. Low-income families may be forced into small, unsafe apartments or long commutes from distant suburbs, which harms health and reduces time for children. Overcrowding can also strain public services such as hospitals, schools and public transport. For businesses, high rents raise wage demands and operating costs, making cities less competitive and pushing essential workersâ€”like nurses and teachersâ€”out of central areas.

Several measures can help. Authorities should increase supply by allowing higher-density building near transport hubs and speeding up approval for well-designed projects. Public housing and rent-support schemes can protect vulnerable groups, while taxes on empty properties can discourage speculation. At the same time, investing in regional development and fast rail links can create attractive job centres outside capital cities, reducing migration pressure.

In summary, urban housing crises damage social stability and economic efficiency. A combination of expanded housing supply, smarter regulation and balanced regional investment is needed to keep cities liveable and inclusive.

essays.title: Are Public Libraries Still Needed?
essays.question:
Some people think public libraries are no longer necessary because of the Internet.
Do you agree or disagree?
body_paragraphs: With smartphones and search engines, it is easy to assume that public libraries have become outdated. I disagree, because libraries now provide far more than printed books: they offer equal access to information, quiet study space and community services that the Internet alone cannot replace.

First, not everyone has reliable devices, fast Wi-Fi or paid subscriptions. Libraries reduce this digital divide by providing computers, internet access and trained staff who can help users find trustworthy sources. This support is crucial for job seekers, elderly people and students from low-income families who may otherwise be excluded from online learning and government services.

Second, libraries serve as community hubs. They offer quiet places for study, childrenâ€™s reading programmes and cultural events such as lectures or language clubs. Unlike cafes, libraries are free and inclusive. They also curate collections, which protects readers from misinformation and helps people explore topics deeply rather than jumping between short online posts.

In conclusion, the Internet has changed how libraries operate, but it has not made them unnecessary. Modern libraries remain valuable public institutions that promote equality, learning and social connection.

essays.title: Taking a Gap Year
essays.question:
Some students take a year off between finishing school and going to university.
What are the advantages and disadvantages of this?
Do you think it is a good idea?
body_paragraphs: Taking a gap year before university has become popular in many countries. It can provide valuable experience and maturity, but it also carries risks such as lost academic momentum. Overall, I think it is a good idea when students have clear goals and a realistic plan.

A gap year can broaden perspectives. Students who travel, volunteer or work often become more independent and confident. Practical experience can also improve career choices; for example, a student who interns in a hospital may confirm an interest in medicine. Earning money during this period can reduce financial pressure at university, especially for families with limited resources.

However, there are disadvantages. Some students find it difficult to return to studying after a year of freedom, and they may forget academic skills. Travelling can be expensive and, without careful planning, a gap year may become unproductive. In addition, delaying graduation means entering the job market later, which could reduce lifetime earnings in certain professions.

In conclusion, a gap year is beneficial if it is structured around meaningful work, learning or service. If students treat it as a planned investment rather than a holiday, the advantages are likely to outweigh the drawbacks.

essays.title: High Salaries for Sports Stars
essays.question:
Some people think that professional athletes are paid too much.
Do you agree or disagree?
body_paragraphs: The salaries of top athletes often seem shocking compared with those of teachers or nurses. While the gap can feel unfair, I mostly disagree that athletes are â€œoverpaidâ€, because their income reflects market demand and the short, risky nature of sporting careers.

Elite sport generates enormous revenue through ticket sales, broadcasting rights and sponsorship. In many cases, athletes receive a share of the money they help create, just as successful entrepreneurs profit from popular products. Moreover, a professional career can end suddenly due to injury, and most athletes peak for only a decade. High pay compensates for this uncertainty and for years of intense training that few people are willing or able to sustain.

That said, there are valid concerns. Sports salaries can encourage a culture that values entertainment more than essential public services. Young people may also chase unrealistic dreams while neglecting education. To address these issues, leagues and governments can promote fair taxation and invest part of sporting profits into grassroots facilities, school programmes and community health projects.

In conclusion, although athletic pay can look excessive, it is largely a result of the economic value of sport and career risk. The priority should be using this wealth responsibly, not artificially limiting earnings.

essays.title: Challenges of an Ageing Population
essays.question:
Many countries are facing an ageing population.
What problems does this cause?
How can these problems be solved?
body_paragraphs: As life expectancy rises and birth rates fall, many countries are becoming older societies. This demographic shift can strain public finances and healthcare systems, but it can be managed through policy reforms and changes in the workplace.

One major problem is pressure on pensions and medical services. With fewer workers supporting more retirees, governments may struggle to fund retirement payments and long-term care. Hospitals can become overcrowded as chronic illnesses such as diabetes and heart disease become more common. Ageing can also slow economic growth if labour shortages reduce productivity and innovation.

Several solutions are available. Raising the retirement age gradually can keep healthy older adults in the workforce and reduce pension burdens. Governments can encourage higher labour participation by supporting childcare, retraining programmes and flexible jobs for seniors. Immigration can also help fill skill gaps. Finally, investing in preventive healthcareâ€”such as exercise campaigns and early screeningâ€”can reduce expensive treatment later.

In summary, ageing populations create fiscal and healthcare challenges, but they are not unmanageable. With smart pension reform, inclusive labour policies and strong prevention, societies can remain prosperous while caring for older citizens.
